qas.question: Who did early court cases focus on?
What could be sued for under civil or criminal law?
What was the result of early law on online liability?

answers.text: varied widely from country to country

qas.question: When were the first laws of liability passed?
Who didn't early court cases focus on?
Who did late court cases focus on?
What couldn't be sued for under civil or criminal law?

plausible_answers.text: varied widely from country to country

qas.question: What was the result of early law on offline liability?
When were the last laws of liability passed?

context: Early court cases focused on the liability of <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>Internet service providers<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> (ISPs) for hosting, transmitting or publishing user-supplied content that could be actioned under civil or criminal law, such as <a1_0><b6_0>libel, defamation, or pornography<b6_0/><a1_0/>. As different content was considered in different legal systems, and in the absence of common definitions for "ISPs," "bulletin boards" or "online publishers," early law on online intermediaries' liability <a2_0><b7_0>varied widely from country to country<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The first laws on online intermediaries' liability were passed from the <a3_0><b8_0>mid-1990s<b8_0/><a3_0/> onwards.[citation needed]
